title: 1062-D
statement: D. Fun with Integerstime limit per test2 secondsmemory limit per test256 megabytesinputstandard inputoutputstandard outputYou are given a positive integer $$$n$$$ greater or equal to $$$2$$$. For every pair of integers $$$a$$$ and $$$b$$$ ($$$2 \\le |a|, |b| \\le n$$$), you can transform $$$a$$$ into $$$b$$$ if and only if there exists an integer $$$x$$$ such that $$$1 < |x|$$$ and ($$$a \\cdot x = b$$$ or $$$b \\cdot x = a$$$), where $$$|x|$$$ denotes the absolute value of $$$x$$$.After such a transformation, your score increases by $$$|x|$$$ points and you arenot allowedto transform $$$a$$$ into $$$b$$$ nor $$$b$$$ into $$$a$$$ anymore.Initially, you have a score of $$$0$$$. You can start at any integer and transform it as many times as you like. What is the maximum score you can achieve?InputA single line contains a single integer $$$n$$$ ($$$2 \\le n \\le 100\\,000$$$) — the given integer described above.OutputPrint an only integer — the maximum score that can be achieved with the transformations. If it is not possible to perform even a single transformation for all possible starting integers, print $$$0$$$.ExamplesInput4Output8Input6Output28Input2Output0NoteIn the first example, the transformations are $$$2 \\rightarrow 4 \\rightarrow (-2) \\rightarrow (-4) \\rightarrow 2$$$.In the third example, it is impossible to perform even a single transformation.

processed.result:
You are given a positive integer $n$ greater than or equal to 2.  You can transform one integer $a$ into another integer $b$ if there exists an integer $x$ such that $1 < |x|$ and either $a \cdot x = b$ or $b \cdot x = a$.  

After transforming $a$ into $b$, your score increases by $|x|$. You cannot transform $a$ into $b$ or $b$ into $a$ again.

Starting with a score of 0, what is the maximum score you can achieve by repeatedly transforming integers?  

Remember:

* $2 \le |a|, |b| \le n$
* You can start with any integer. 
* If no transformations are possible, the maximum score is 0.

You have a number *n*. You can change one number to another if you can multiply it by a number between 1 and *n* (excluding 1).  Each time you change a number, you get points equal to the absolute value of the multiplier. You can change a number as many times as you want, but you can't change it back to the original number. What is the highest number of points you can get?
